doc.field: Big Ben guide, Catherine Moss, and a group of Enthusiasts, pose with the Great Bell. In May 2009 Big Ben underwent cleaning and conservation for its special anniversary. This work ensures Big Ben is protected from the weather and its appearance improved. This image is subject to <a href"http:www.parliament.uksite_informationparliamentary_copyright.cfm#images" target"_self" rel"nofollow">parliamentary copyright<a>. Big Ben with Portcullis House in the foreground. Portcullis House contains offices for MPs and a suite of modern meeting and Select Committee rooms. It was completed in 2000 and was officially opened in February 2001. Visit the UK Parliament website for more information on <a href"http:www.parliament.ukaboutlivingheritagebuildingportcullishouse.cfm" rel"nofollow">Portcullis House<a>. This image shows Big Ben's damaged clock mechanism in 1976. At first thought to have been caused by a bomb, the damage actually resulted from the sudden fracture of the flyfan arbor of the chiming train. Consequently, there was no check on the 112 ton weight of the chiming mechanism, and wheels, gears, cams and clicks were flung at high speed around the clockroom, and even through the ceiling. No one was hurt, because the accident happened at 4am. This image is subject to <a href"http:www.parliament.uksite_informationparliamentary_copyright.cfm#images" target"_self">parliamentary copyright<a>. <a href"http:www.parliament.ukbigben">Visit the Parliament website<a> for more information about the Clock Tower.

Big Ben: Damage to the clock mechanism 5 August 1976

The Clock Tower (Big Ben) mechanics use pre-1971 coins to alter the speed of the clock's pendulum. This picture shows a tin with some of the coins and the log sheet the mechanics use when they're correcting the speed of the pendulum. These images are subject to <a href"http:www.parliament.uksite_informationparliamentary_copyright.cfm#images" target"_self">parliamentary copyright<a>. <a href"http:www.parliament.ukbigben">Visit the Parliament website<a> for more information about the Clock Tower.

A group of Enthusiasts get up close to Big Ben. Enthusiasts chose which theory for Big Benâ€™s name they liked best: whether it was after Sir Benjamin Hall MP, Commissioner of Works when the bell was installed, or after Benjamin Caunt, a champion heavyweight boxer of the 1850s. Engineers install the scaffold to lift the strike train drum which operates Big Ben, the hour bell, in order to replace the main bearings (it is believed that these are the original bearings from 1859). <a href"http:www.parliament.ukbigben">Visit the parliamentary website <a>for more information about maintenance of the Clock Tower.
uk london westminster unitedkingdom politics housesofparliament parliament commons bigben clocktower mp lords peers houseoflords houseofcommons mps ukparliament

Two months after Big Ben was installed in the Clock Tower a crack appeared in the bell. This was caused by the use of a hammer twice the recommended weight for the bell. Big Ben was taken out of service for three years. During this time hours were struck on the largest of the quarter bells. A hole was drilled at the top and bottom of the crack to stop it growing and the bell was rotated a quarter turn clockwise when reinstalled. This gives the bell a distinct but slightly less than perfect tone. <a href"http:www.parliament.ukbigben">Visit the Parliament website<a> for more information about the history of the Clock Tower
uk london westminster unitedkingdom politics housesofparliament parliament commons bigben clocktower mp lords peers houseoflords houseofcommons mps ukparliament

Enthusiasts were provided with earplugs to put in just before the hour strike. Big Benâ€™s strikes measure 117 decibels which is louder than a jet engine. The clockmakers always wear ear-defenders when theyâ€™re in the belfry as long-term exposure to these levels of noise can be hazardous. Saturday 11 July coincided with the 150th anniversary of Big Ben - the hour bell - striking for the first time in partnership with the Great Clock. The large barrel in the foreground of this image is the striking train which starts Big Benâ€™s strikes on the hour. This image is subject to <a href"http:www.parliament.uksite_informationparliamentary_copyright.cfm#images" target"_self" rel"nofollow">parliamentary copyright<a>. The centre of each dial is 55 metres above the ground. Because the tower is built outwards at this level, there is nothing but air beneath the floor where the Enthusiasts are standing. Big Ben Enthusiasts: Behind the dials

The Clock Tower is the famous tower of the Houses of Parliament and contains the bell known as Big Ben. The Clock Tower is 95.7 metres tall. This image is subject to <a href"http:www.parliament.uksite_informationparliamentary_copyright.cfm#images" target"_self">parliamentary copyright<a>. <a href"http:www.parliament.ukbigben">Visit the Parliament website<a> for more information about the Clock Tower.
